Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Rabbi Arthur Schneier Papers
Schneier, Arthur, Rabbi
TAM.694
106.75 Linear Feet in 82 record cartons, 9 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, 4 oversize flat boxes, and 1 small flat box
1960-2012 Rabbi Arthur Schneier lived under Nazi occupation in Budapest until age 17 and immigrated to the United States in 1947. In 1955, Schneier received his rabbinical ordination from Yeshiva University. He has served as the Senior Rabbi of New York City's Park East Synagogue. Schneier has been an active member and leader of prominent international religious and political relations' councils. This collection consists of materials created and collected by Rabbi Arthur Schneier in the course of his personal and professional life as a rabbi and activist concerned with international religious freedom and human rights efforts. Materials include correspondence, photographs, memoranda, subject files on various countries, and other materials concerning his involvement with the Foreign Service Institute and his international trips, with particular emphasis on China and the Soviet Union. The collection also includes materials documenting his participating in the Appeal of Conscience Foundation and their annual awards dinner. Materials are in English.
Conditions Governing Access
Access to this collection is restricted, with the exception of digital surrogates of materials in boxes 111 and 157.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
The collection was donated by Rabbi Arthur Schneier in 2017. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 2017.035, 2017.067, and 2017.075.
Arrangement
The arrangement of the collection and titles of each series are based on the original order of the records as maintained by Rabbi Arthur Schneier and Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives' Curator, Michael Koncewicz. Original folder titles were retained. Routine financial statements, duplicate publications, and documents with sensitive personal information were removed. The collection is organized into eight series:
Series 1: Foreign Service Institute (FSI)
Series 2: Correspondence
Series 3: Clippings
Series 4: Annual Award Dinner (AAD)
Series 5: Country Files
Series 6: Photographs
Series 7: Conference Files
Series 8: Internal Alliance of Civilizations (AoC) Records/Miscellaneous.
Biographical Note
Rabbi Arthur Schneier (1930- ) was born on March 20, 1930 in Vienna, Austria, and lived under Nazi occupation in Budapest until age 17. Schneier immigrated to the United States in 1947. He graduated with a Bachelor of Arts from Yeshiva University in 1951 and earned a Masters of Arts from New York University in 1953. In 1955, Schneier received his rabbinical ordination from Yeshiva University. He has served for over 50 years as the Senior Rabbi of New York City's Park East Synagogue. Over the years, he has been an active member of many prominent religious and political relations' councils including: the Council on Foreign Relations, United Nations Development Corporation, and the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum committee. Schneier serves as Vice President of the World Jewish Congress American Section. Schneier encourages interfaith dialogue, cultural understanding, and the religious freedom for all citizens of the world.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Rabbi Arthur Schneier Papers; TAM 694; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information
At the time of accessioning, July 2017, most of the materials were left in their original file folders and housed primarily in record cartons with spacers as a means to reflect the box inventory written by Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives' Curator, Michael Koncewicz. Further accretions were rehoused in appropriately sized boxes but the original box numbering from the inventory has been maintained.
Scope and Contents
This collection consists of materials created and collected by Rabbi Arthur Schneier in the course of his personal and professional life as a rabbi and activist concerned with international religious freedom and human rights efforts. Materials include correspondence, photographs, memoranda, subject files on various countries, and other materials concerning his involvement with the Foreign Service Institute and his international trips, with particular emphasis on China and the Soviet Union. The collection also includes materials documenting his participating in the Appeal of Conscience Foundation and their annual awards dinner.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Rabbi Arthur Schneier, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
United States -- Foreign relations. China Jews -- Soviet Union Religion and social problems. Politics and culture. Faxes. Clippings files. International relations.
